1-1.title: Emancipation Proclamation
1-1.description: President Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation took effect, freeing enslaved people in Confederate states.

1-15.title: Martin Luther King Jr. Born
1-15.description: Civil rights leader Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was born in Atlanta, Georgia.

2-1.title: Langston Hughes Born
2-1.description: Legendary poet and leader of the Harlem Renaissance was born in Joplin, Missouri.

2-1.title: Greensboro Sit-ins Begin
2-1.description: Four Black college students began a sit-in at a segregated Woolworth's lunch counter.

2-1.title: 13th Amendment Signed
2-1.description: President Lincoln signed the resolution proposing the 13th Amendment to abolish slavery.

2-2.title: Truman's Civil Rights Message
2-2.description: President Truman sent a special message to Congress on civil rights.

2-2.title: Alfred L. Cralle Patents Ice Cream Scoop
2-2.description: Black inventor Alfred L. Cralle patented the ice cream scoop.

2-3.title: 15th Amendment Ratified
2-3.description: The 15th Amendment was ratified, prohibiting denial of voting rights based on race.

2-3.title: Autherine Lucy at University of Alabama
2-3.description: Autherine Lucy became the first Black student to attend the University of Alabama.

2-4.title: Rosa Parks Born
2-4.description: Civil rights activist Rosa Parks was born in Tuskegee, Alabama.

2-4.title: France Abolishes Slavery
2-4.description: Revolutionary France became the first European power to abolish slavery.

2-5.title: Hank Aaron Born
2-5.description: Baseball legend Hank Aaron was born in Mobile, Alabama.

2-5.title: Jesse Jackson Wins Primaries
2-5.description: Jesse Jackson won presidential primaries in Alabama and Georgia.

2-6.title: First Great Migration
2-6.description: 86 free Black Americans sailed from New York to Sierra Leone, marking early African colonization.

2-6.title: Bob Marley Born
2-6.description: Reggae legend Bob Marley was born in Nine Mile, Jamaica.

2-7.title: Negro History Week Begins
2-7.description: Carter G. Woodson launched the first Negro History Week, precursor to Black History Month.

2-7.title: South African Ban Lifted
2-7.description: The South African government lifted its ban on the African National Congress.

2-8.title: Orangeburg Massacre
2-8.description: Three Black students were killed by South Carolina Highway Patrol during a protest.

2-8.title: Boy Scouts Integrated Vision
2-8.description: The Boy Scouts of America was founded with a vision that would eventually include all races.

2-9.title: Alice Walker Born
2-9.description: Pulitzer Prize-winning author Alice Walker was born in Eatonton, Georgia.

2-10.title: Alex Haley Passes
2-10.description: Author of 'Roots' Alex Haley passed away, leaving an incredible literary legacy.

2-10.title: Leontyne Price Born
2-10.description: Opera legend Leontyne Price was born in Laurel, Mississippi.

2-21.title: Malcolm X Assassinated
2-21.description: Civil rights leader Malcolm X was assassinated in New York City.

2-23.title: W.E.B. Du Bois Born
2-23.description: Sociologist and NAACP co-founder W.E.B. Du Bois was born in Massachusetts.

4-4.title: Martin Luther King Jr. Assassinated
4-4.description: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee.

5-17.title: Brown v. Board of Education
5-17.description: Supreme Court ruled that racial segregation in public schools was unconstitutional.

6-19.title: Juneteenth
6-19.description: News of emancipation reached Texas, marking the end of slavery in the last Confederate state.

8-28.title: March on Washington
8-28.description: Over 250,000 people gathered for the March on Washington where MLK delivered 'I Have a Dream' speech.

8-28.title: Emmett Till Murdered
8-28.description: 14-year-old Emmett Till was murdered in Mississippi, galvanizing the civil rights movement.

12-1.title: Rosa Parks Arrested
12-1.description: Rosa Parks was arrested for refusing to give up her bus seat, sparking the Montgomery Bus Boycott.

default.title: First Africans Arrive in America
default.description: The first recorded Africans arrived in the English colonies at Point Comfort, Virginia.

default.title: End of Civil War
default.description: The Civil War ended, beginning the era of Reconstruction.

default.title: Brown v. Board of Education
default.description: Supreme Court ruled that racial segregation in public schools was unconstitutional.

default.title: March on Washington
default.description: Over 250,000 gathered for the March on Washington, where MLK delivered 'I Have a Dream' speech.

default.title: Barack Obama Elected
default.description: Barack Obama was elected as the 44th President, becoming the first Black president of the United States.
